raw_comment:
Immediately, I noticed how a stacked area chart is being utilized to visualize the data presented. The issue with using a stacked area chart like these graphs is that it is difficult to determine the actual size of one section in the chart since each section is built on top of one another like layers of sediment. This also makes it difficult to visually see trends in specific sections since their baselines are all different and affected by the layers below. I also noticed how it appears clean energy sources have increased in the past 22 years, specifically how much wind and solar have exploded recently. 
I wonder how the U.S. has stayed fairly consistent with energy production when it feels as if electricity has become more and more integral to life each day in the twenty-first century. Similarly, on the opposite side, why has China’s production boomed so much?
These graphs relate to me and my community because as climate change continues and natural fossil fuels begin to run out, the need for sustainable energy sources and better energy consumption practices is more important than ever. Keeping energy use steady, or even decreasing is something that we as a community should strive for. Additionally, by making sure we continue to switch more and more to clean energy production, we are helping the prosperity and longevity of the planet and our own futures. 
Title: “A Decade of the World’s Energy: Is Clean Power the Future?”
